DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Facility has less than the threshold quantity for chlorine

_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Severe storms(thunderstorms, blizzards), epiodemic, drought, insect infestation, vector-borne diseases, hostile attack, civil disorder, terrorist activity, transportation accidents, dam failure.
_prev_prog_2.Description: The chlorine unit has a chemicl metering pump with positive-displacement, diaphragm type pump.The pump is equipped with a flowmwter-pulser assembly, that automatically stops pulsating when discharge pressure exceeds pump pressure, and when power source is gone.  The pump also , has a four function valve assembly with positive anti-syphon feature and back pressure function making chemical dicharges without overpumping due to dicharge velocity.  There are also primimg -line pressure release, and a pressure relief function, to relieve against back-pressure. Any back pressure isreleased back into the chemical solution via polyethlyene tubing.  The solution tank has an overflow drain that is directed to flow into the city sewer lines.  In summary, the chlorine unit has a foot valve assemby that consists of a bal check valveand strainer, allowing the chlorinwe solution to flow in one direction only and preventing it from droppong back into the tank.  Followedby another ballcheck valve before entering the pump head.  The pump head is a positive-displacement diaphragm pump, allowing only a metered amount of solution through a combination anti-syphon/pressure relief valve into the discharge tubing into an injection valve, also containing a ball check valvethat is spring loaded.  Any accidental spills of the chlorine solution are covered with a clay absorbant and disposed of properly.  NOTE: The chlorine solution utilized is diluted by 50%, so as to feed a 6% solution with a 30% stroke frequency.

_exec_summary.SummaryText: The community of Fort Kipp is located within the southeast corner of the Fort Peck Indian Reservstion along U.S. Highway No. 2.  Approximately nine (9) miles West of Culbertson and a twenty-two (22) miles East of Poplar within Roosevelt County.  Fort Kipp has 38 service connections, a church, two (2) community centers, head Start, laundromat, playground, Tribal ceremonial/pow-wow grounds, uses approximately 15,000 gallons of water per day.  The water is pumped from one well source within the community.  Fort Kipp is sustained by farming, ranching and basic services.  The original water system was designed and constructed in the early 70's and consisted of a well, pump hous, controls, water distribution system(4" watermains), and a strosge fzcility.  the storage facility consists of an 40,000 gallon underground tank.  The pump house has a chlorinator system that was installed 1992, upon bacteriological contamination.  The chlorinator systemconsists of a 50 gallon solution tank, a positive-displacement pump with back pressurerelief/anti-syphon valve.  The chlorine unit, is a metering pump that can be regulated between internal and external pulsing by means of a switch with frequency control knob.  The pump drive is totally encapsulated in a chemical resistant housing to provide for maximum protection against chemical spillage.  Chemical metering pump valves are ball check valves seated on combination valve seat and seal ring, that are routinely checked and replaced as they get worn.  The four fucntion valve provides protection against chemical overloading and spillage, with negative pressure at discharge closing the diaphragm and preventing syphoning.  The pressure relief function de-pressurizes the discharge line preventing chemical overpumping and possible line ruptures.
